data.text: Bikepacking Kit for Week-Long Bike Trips
Would love to try Bike packing. For you experienced Bikepackers what's your kit look like for a week long trip? Currently have zero equipment lol Salsa Timberjack 2018
Youll get 10x more information carrying out a search... countless threads on people's setup
data.author: Jordan Salkeld

data.text: I'll do that as well. Thanks
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: Front & Rear Racks for me! I like to be comfortable when going on longer trips personally üòé
data.author: Ashley Burton

data.text: It all depends on how many restock opportunities you‚Äôll have during the week, as well as water resupply opportunities. Start with a frame bag and a handlebar roll. And bike a few overnighter trips to get a feel.
data.author: Keith ODaniel

data.text: thanks. i'm thinking BWCA so limited restocking. ideally pack it all in.
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: You will need a bag in the rear then. The elongated, frameless seat bags really suck. You‚Äôre always having to fiddle with them, they swing all over the place, and they interfere with your dropper post. There are rear bag frames on the market now that don‚Äôt attach to the seat and don‚Äôt interfere with a dropper post. I‚Äôd look into one of those.
data.author: Keith ODaniel

data.text: thanks for the heads up on those.
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: you know you can't bike in the BWCAW, right? My Salsa Timberjack loaded up for an overnight, pretty much everything I'd need for a week, aside from food- that could be tough if you couldn't resupply food, every couple of days.
data.author: Jason Busch

data.text: could bike to it and meet with the crew who has canoes and boats üòâ or some deep woods off road stuff lol. "where there a will....."

data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: 27# tops for gear including food and water. Bike is around 30 itself. But I'm not really an ounce counter. ü§∑üòÅ
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: The stem bag or "top tank" is made by 2wheel gear out of Canada. Good stuff. I also have a cheap soft water bottle holder/feed bag on either side of it. Room for everything üòÅ
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: I recently completed the TNGA with this Timberjack rig in 6 days. There were a few items I brought and didn‚Äôt use and a few items I‚Äôd wish I had brought, though I wouldn‚Äôt have packed any heavier than what‚Äôs depicted, in hindsight.
data.author: Keith ODaniel

data.text: looks great. how many pounds of gear? good source for bike packing gear?
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: I didn‚Äôt weigh the bike. Their are lots of custom bag makers out there. Most of mine were made by Spindle in Atlanta - Spindle is a ten minute bike ride from my house. The only custom bag you‚Äôll need is the frame bag. The rest can be purchased online, off the shelf.
data.author: Keith ODaniel

data.text: that's awesome man! Any tire advice if you're loaded with gear? setup tubeless at the moment.
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text:
Carry your tools all in a tool roll for easy access, and carry the tools in your frame bag, rather than in the rear or front of the bike. Make sure you have all the tools you'll need because it's a given something(s) will go wrong. There's a good video on bikepacking.com on what tools to carry. Tubeless setup is key. If you are going to be out there for a week, change out the sealent with race day sealent - it's only good for a couple of weeks but it's like cottage cheese and will cut down the chance of a flat by 60%. Also make sure you have plugs with you. And extra sealant.
BIKEPACKING.com - Bikepacking Routes, Gear, Inspiration
bikepacking.com
data.author: Keith ODaniel

data.text: awesome! i check out the website too. get some ideas. how far were you going per day o. your trips?
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: That all depends on the terrain and elevation. Think in terms of hours on the bike instead of miles. I generally ride 9 to 18 hours which includes necessary stops for food, water, navigating and repairs.

data.author: Dean Wolfgang

data.text: This was 6 days. I love being as light as possible. I keep it super simple. Food all together in the top tube bad. Sleeping bag, tarp, mat, spare clothes in the rear. Down jacket, the essentials, gps, etc up front.
data.author: Tom Cockerton
Dusty Kuykendall

data.text: As JFK once said, "Ask not your countrymen what you can search on Google or YouTube."
data.author: Epi Fabonan III

data.text: wise words and ahead of his time lol.
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: Here is my Timberjack. This is my standard week to multi week load out. Your setup will evolve as you gain experience. When choosing gear I use simplicity, ease of loading/unloading, weather proof, and the ability to be comfortable in varying weather conditions as my guide. Weight has never been a factor for me. If I need/want it, I pack it.
data.author: Peter Kranenburg

data.text: that's awesome!
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: This was my setup for 6 days on the Maah Daah Hey trail in the Badlands of ND. Fully self supported. No stores, no gas stations. It's all Revelate. Salty Roll up front with a Feedbag on each side of the stem, full frame bag(dont remember the model), Nano Panniers and I'm still using the Terrapin seat bag without the harness. I just strapped it to the top of the rack. Not exactly an ultra light setup. This bike weighed about 75 pounds fully loaded. I also had a small day pack with bladder on my back. The bike is a Specialized Carbon Comp in size small. The struggle is real.üòÑ
data.author: Mike Spencer

data.text: that looks great man! A badlands trip on hike would be amazing.
data.author: Steve Johnston
Rex Villanueva

data.text: With fat tires
data.author: Rex Villanueva

data.text: Something to bear n mind is the only real difference between a overnighter/weekend trip and a longer one is amount of food and maybe clothes you take. With a quick trip, you usually more accurately know the weather forecast. On longer trips you may need to bring more clothing in case weather changes and also for a fresh clothing change, if you can't launder.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: thoughts on a bike trailer?
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: It's personal preference. You can carry everything on a bike fairly easily, so unless taking a dog or small child, I wouldn't use one myself. If any cycling mates have some kit see if you can borrow it to test. A local bike shop has bikepacking bags to rent to test for that very reason.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: planning to get one to start taking my son on some rides, but not sure if take him on a bike packing trip for a while.
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: Get the hang of bikepacking, before taking kids along.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence
Andreas Madreiter

data.text: My last overnight trip. Packed heavy for comfort at camp so it would look the same for multi day. Maybe adding a hip pack.
data.author: Johnathan Stuckey

data.text: It depends. You can go pretty far with a couple water bottles and a credit card. If I‚Äôm camping I always bring a chair.
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: This is not an exhaustive list, it's more like a top of my head rough guide. Travelling you will learn. Try to start small ( 1,2 days) and only after you have an idea, jump for a week of riding. The 2nd photo doesn't belong to me, I just took it of the net to present you an idea of carrying your stuff.
data.author: Adrian Calaciu

data.text: thanks for the list. hoping to get a trip in this fall.
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: If you're camping, then you'll be bringing both camping and riding gear. Myself- I poured through bikepacking sites, gear lists. I followed ultralight backpacking gear lists for my climate as another resource. There are whole articles & countless videos on just bikepacking rain jackets, so enjoy the discovery process. I lean very much to the comfort side as I'm just living my best life. Others pack as minimally as possible for speed and distance.
data.author: Mike Kehoe

data.text: Basic outdoor essentials and bike repair. The particulars don't matter. I score lots of quality gear at thrift stores and on Poshmark/eBay for pennies on the dollar. I always bring an emergency whistle. And I like to shave so I can feel human and like bringing a small mirror (also because in my head all trips end with a helicopter rescue and I have a survival fantasy where my mirror saves my life).
data.author: Andy Decker

data.text: We do hotels (I know, not really bikepacking), so just extra clothes, tools, toiletries, a few protein bars and miscellaneous. Stuff that all in a pair of rear panniers.
data.author: Dave Elmstrom

data.text: nothing wrong with that if you're exploring on the bikes. Sounds awesome üëç
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: 5 day semi self supported trip through the Elk horns in Eastern Oregon. 200 miles 28k elevation. Salsa carry anything cradle on the bars with a Roadrunner handlebar bag(snacks), with 2 bartender bags for water. The forks have Blackburn cages with Roadrunner bags. I made the frame bag myself to utilize wasted space my old Blackburn left. Revelate seat bag. I used a Platypus 2 liter bladder in the bottom of the frame bag with a port to run the hose to the cockpit. Water was a concern several days of the trip, so we were loaded heavy those days.
data.author: Kevin Riley

data.text: that's fantastic!
data.author: Steve Johnston

data.text: I forgot the double footed kick stand. The others in my group were pretty jealous.
data.author: Kevin Riley

data.text: Ortlieb handlebar bag, Ova Negra feedbag, Topeak saddlebag. Along with my noname amazon hip pack. Carries my one person tent, quilt, inflatable pad and pillow, one change of clothes, two changes of socks, sandals, and set of long underwear. Spare battery, wires, and snacks go in my feedbag. Tools and toiletries and weed go in my hip bag.
data.author: Ben Grad

data.text: Ortlieb panniers (front and back). üôÇ

data.text: Tent, pillow, sleeping matt in rear seat bag, stove, gas, food, spares in frame bag and sleeping bag, spare t shirt, mid layer, waterproof in handlebar bag

data.text: My kit stays the same for a one nighter or a week long .... just add more food and fuel and a couple more base layers.

Marc Irwin

data.text: Your 1 week kit is the same as your 2 day kit. Decide if camping. If yes, get the most insulated sleeping mat you can for size. Match to a sleeping bag for the minimum temp you are willing to camp out in. I‚Äôm not a 4 season camper. 3 at most. Down to 30deg F. Then, 1 pair shorts, one set of apr√©s riding gear, one packable quilt jacket. Small towel. Fill in the blanks.
data.author: Steven Fish
